6.text: making them favourite observational targets for astronomers

11.text: Hubble has observed its fair share of these cosmic baubles,

16.text: imaging and studying them to explore their secrets.

21.text: This new image from Hubble shows a globular cluster known as Messier 15

29.text: As well as containing over 100 000 old stars, this cluster hosts something dark and mysterious at its heart.

54.text: Hubblecast 69: What has Hubble learned from star clusters?

60.text: Star clusters are some of the most beautiful objects in our skies

66.text: Hubble has viewed many of these over the years — but it is not all style over substance

72.text: These clusters are incredibly useful to the astronomers studying them

78.text: What can they tell us about our Universe?

85.text: There are two main types of star cluster:

97.text: Most stars, including the Sun, are thought to have formed within open star clusters

104.text: groups of thousands of stars loosely bound together by gravity

109.text: destined to be spread throughout their host galaxy once the cluster matures and most of its gas disperses.

118.text: Globular clusters are different; they are huge balls of old stars that orbit the centres of galaxies

127.text: Many of them were once little galaxies, cannibalised by their larger companions over the history of the Universe.

139.text: Hubble has explored many globular clusters

142.text: The Milky Way alone has over 150 of these starry satellites, and Hubble’s sharp vision can resolve the individual stars.

153.text: This has allowed Hubble to explore these star clusters in unprecedented detail.

162.text: Hubble has produced the deepest, most detailed images ever of a galaxy outside our own: the Andromeda galaxy,

173.text: spotting individual star clusters and even resolving their separate stars.

181.text: It has detected a population of white dwarfs within NGC 6397

187.text: These ancient, dying stars are the dimmest stars ever seen in any globular cluster.

195.text: They led to the first accurate measurements of cluster ages.

202.text: Hubble has also spotted the largest collection of globular clusters ever found,

207.text: a staggering 160 000, swarming around at the heart of the galaxy cluster Abell 1689.

218.text: It has probed the Milky Way’s clusters to understand how different stars age at different rates,

226.text: and investigated why some clusters seem to host multiple generations of stars while others contain stars of mostly the same age.

243.text: Now, Hubble has looked towards the globular cluster Messier 15,

249.text: one of the oldest globular clusters known in our galaxy, at around 12 billion years old.

256.text: This image of Messier 15 is reminiscent of a dazzling firework display, with golden and bright blue stars swarming together across the frame.

270.text: Messier 15 houses a planetary nebula known as Pease 1 — making it the first globular ever known to contain one of these objects

281.text: Even now, only three other similar clusters have been found to host such a planetary nebula.

290.text: However, all it not as it seems —

293.text: this sparkling bauble has hidden secrets

298.text: Astronomers studying Messier 15 with Hubble in 2002 found there to be something dark and mysterious lurking at its heart.

309.text: There are two possible explanations for this intriguing finding

313.text: It could either be a collection of dark, incredibly dense neutron stars, or a rare and exotic intermediate-mass black hole

324.text: Studying these unusual black holes could tell us about how such objects grow and evolve within both star clusters and galaxies.
